loans.name: Rico

texts.en:
Rico R. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de City. She is 53 years old and single. To make a living, Rico owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rico has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rico joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rico is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the fourth loan that Rico has taken out  from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and provide working capital

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Bendera

texts.en:
Bendera is a married woman with four girls and a boy, aged between six and 18 years, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Bendera’s greatest monthly expenses are food and clothing for her children.

She has operated her charcoal sale business for over one year, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she sells fresh tap water contributing to her other source of income. Bendera faces the major challenge of transportation and seasonality in her business. During the rainy winter season, the supply of charcoal is lower than the demand hence the low sales volume unlike the hot summer season when supply is higher than the demand. She hopes to purchase her own plot in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal. Her main aim of working with Yehu is to get loans to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Jackline Akinyi

texts.en:
Jackline is married and they have three children whom they support.

Jackline joined KADET through other group members. She is servicing a third loan and has been repaying successfully.  She has been in the clothing business for 10 years with a good income at the end of each month. With this loan, Jackline plans to purchase additional stock of secondhand clothes for her stall.

With the profits, Jackline will open another clothes outlet. She hopes her business will succeed so that she can meet her family's basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Analyne

texts.en:
Analyne B. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 37 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Analyne owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Analyne has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Analyne joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Analyne is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan that Analyne has taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Burulbubu's Group

texts.en:
Burulbubu B. is the leader of the group. She is 37 and a widow. She has raised two sons and a daughter. All the children attend school. Burulbubu works as a social worker and receives a monthly salary in the amount of 3600 soms. She is also engaged in cattle breeding. She applied for the loan because she needs money to improve her living conditions and purchase household appliances. 

Aikul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 45 and married. Her husband works in construction and earns 8000 soms per month. They have four sons. The two older sons are working in construction and the other sons are at school. Aikul hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase wood to start repairing the house. In the future she wants to purchase a house in Bishkek.

Sezim M. is 21. She works in a sewing workshop. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase cement to start repairing the house.

Liza T., 34, is married. She has three daughters and two sons. Her husband is handicapped, so Liza earns money to cover family expenses by herself. She is engaged in cattle breeding. She makes 3000 soms per month reselling cattle after fattening. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for cattle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase household appliances

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma J., aged 49, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Rogelio J., a driver, and is the mother of two children, both of whom are studying. The elder child is in high school while the other is enrolled in elementary. By the grace of God, Norma has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Norma as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Norma maintains a variety store and a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, frozen cuts of meat and other products mostly through the popular direct selling brand, Avon, and a popular local meat brand.  A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer’s cost price is lower than the price in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers earn as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 600 in sales every day from her variety store and direct selling business.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Norma dreams of being able to give both her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Jerson

texts.en:
Jerson L. is from the village of Biasong. He is 22 years old and is married. To make a living, Jerson owns and operates a manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling clay products to local businesses and community members. Jerson has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jerson joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Jerson is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the third loan that Jerson has taken out from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma L., aged 33, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Angelito L. and is the mother of a young boy who is now at preparatory school. By the grace of God, Gemma has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Gemma as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Gemma maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer’s cost prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers earn as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 700 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Gemma is requesting a PHP 22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Gemma dreams of being able to give her child a good, high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Marcelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to repair her fishing boat. Marcelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This will be the fifth loan that Marcelita has taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.name: Genie

texts.en:
Genie T., aged 57, is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Roel T. and mother to four hard-working young adults. By the grace of God, Genie has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Genie operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale price and selling at the piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Genie dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Juliana Mutindi

texts.en:
Juliana is married and they have one child whom she supports. She was introduced to KADET LTD by existing clients of KADET. Juliana is servicing a third loan from KADET after repaying her previous loans well and on time.  Juliana has been in the boutique business for three years. With the loan, Juliana will purchase clothes to sale in her boutique.The business is located in Kayole, a very busy place and most of her customers are the area's residents.

With the profits, Juliana will build some rental houses on her piece of land. She hopes to build rental rooms and maximize her income.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell in her boutique.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from buying and selling coconuts and bananas in the local community. Nening has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Nening joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nening is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This will be the fifth loan that Nening has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Uth

texts.en:
Mrs. Uth L. is 50 years old and her husband, Vorn Srin, is 52. They work from home making furniture which they also sell. Most of their output consists of beds and tables which they accumulate and sell as sets. Their furniture is made mostly from wood and rattan. The couple has five children, two of whom are in school and who, when school ends for the day, help their parents make furniture. The three remaining are married and live in their new house. 

Mrs. Uth L. said that she has difficulty in transporting her finished products to her clients when she receives orders.  So Mrs. Uth L. would like to borrow a loan to purchase a horse and cart to deliver items to customers.

loans.use: To purchase a horse and cart for delivering her items to customers

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida T. is from the village of Brgy. Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old, married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Aida is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase the crop yield. This will be the fourth loan that Aida has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is the rent bill.  

For over seven years, she has operated her business of selling fried fish and also operates a retail shop where she sells maize flour, sugar and cooking oil to her neighbors. Rukia's major challenge is seasonality. During the August holidays the demand for fish is very high compared to the months of January and February. She hopes to expand in the future and open another business.

She decided to join Yehu so as to access loans to boost her business. With the 50,000 KES she wants to purchase a bundle of fish, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of fish, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.name: Jursun's Group

texts.en:
Jursun A. is the leader of the group. She is 70 years old and married.  Her husband is a pensioner. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS,  Jursun and her husband started to breed livestock.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase three sheep in order to increase the number of livestock. With the rest of the money she will purchase paint to start repairing her house. 

Aiganysh T. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 53 and married. Her husband is a pensioner. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 KGS, Aiganysh and her husband started to breed cattle.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for the cattle. 

Ulan U., 35, is married. He has three sons and a daughter, all of whom go to school. Ulan works as a taxi driver and his wife is a schoolteacher.  Two years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS, Ulan bought four sheep and started to breed livestock. With the money received from the loan he wants to purchase hay in order to feed the animals during the winter.

Elmart T. U. is 20 years old. He works as a taxi driver and also breeds livestock. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase five sheep for breeding, and part of the loan he will use to purchase auto parts for his vehicle. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. loans.name: Daisy Caballa Group

texts.en:
Daisy C. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Daisy is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Daisy is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fourteen years and earns approximately $66 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Daisy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Daisy is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.ru: Акрамов Саиджон проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 41 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Саиджон имеет средне - специальное образование, шафер. По специальности не работает. He no longer works in that field.  Currently, he is involved in retail sales at a market.  He has a retail outlet, where he sells fabrics.  Saidjon has been in this business for 13 years.  He is requesting this loan in order to expand his merchandise selection because the demand for his goods will increase before the holiday.

loans.use: Expanding merchandise selection

Khlang R. depends on the income from her children, who work at different jobs. Her daughter always needs to hire a taxi to deliver her to work because she has no a vehicle. Khlang R. is looking for a loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle to aid with her daughter's traveling.

loans.name: Asylkan

texts.en:
Asylkan D. is young farmer who lives in Shopokov village in the northern part of Kyrgyzstan. She is 26, married, and has one son aged four.  Her husband works at the woodworking plant and makes all his efforts to provide his family with essentials. Unfortunately, his salary is very low and doesn’t meet all expenses. In order to find an additional means of subsistence and support for her family, Asylkan started her business in cattle breeding. She bought cattle for fattening and reselling and concentrated all her efforts on supporting and expanding her household. Revenues from this activity allowed Asylkan to buy a small house in the village. Also she started to breed ducks, which became her favorite hobby.

Now Asylkan wants to take a loan of 90,000 KGS to buy bull-calves for fattening and forage for cattle. With the revenues from this investment, Asylkan  plans to give a good education to her son. In the future, she plans to develop her farm by means of livestock breeding. As for her dreams, Asylkan is fond of American culture and wants to see Chicago some day. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Gulniza's Group

texts.en:
Gulniza A. is the leader of the group. She is 22 and single. She makes her living by working as a seller in her sister’s shop. Two years ago they decided to start a shop to sell beverages and foodstuff. Later they cooked and sold national food in the nearer canteen. In order to purchase foodstuff for further resale Gulniza hopes to get a loan. In the future, she is planning to get the manager’s position and to get married. 

Abdurahim L. is 31 and married. His wife is a seamstress. Together the couple has two children, one of whom goes to school. Five years ago his parents gave him a calf and a sheep and since then he has been engaged in cattle breeding. With the profits he purchased a sewing machine for his wife and also made house repairs. Abdurahim wants a loan to buy four livestock animals and to finish the house repairs. In the future, Abdurahim wants to purchase a house in Bishkek City.

Tatyana L. is 55 and married. Her spouse is a farmer. The couple has two daughters who are 36 and 31 years old. The elder one is a  seamstress and the younger one is currently unemployed. Tatyana earns money by working as a guard and a charwoman in a school. Tatyana wants a loan to make household improvements. In future, the family is planning to make house repairs and to separate daughters.

Nazokat T. is 39, married and has two children. Her spouse, who supports the family, is a taxi driver. Nazokat works as a charwoman. Her family needs to a loan in order to make house repairs and to arrange her son’s circumcision. In the future, Nazokat is planning to finish the house repairs, plant roses around the house, and purchase a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff

loans.name: Barnabas

texts.en:
Barnabas W. has been in the transport business for about three years and earns a profit of KES 10000 per month. The business location is in Obunga, Kisumu City. He is married to Eunice Atieno, who manages a water kiosk that helps to add income to the family. They have three children, a seven year old and twins who are one and a half.

Barnabas was introduced to KADET Ltd. through market awareness done in the area. He has no history with any other microfinance organization, and he is applying for a second loan of KES 60000, after paying the previous loan successfully. He plans to buy another motorbike to improve his transport services. The profit will be used to support his family by providing the basic needs.

In the future, he plans to grow his business so that it is stable and will provide a good flow of income.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike

loans.name: Nelma

texts.en:
Nelma D. is from the village of Dalirig, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Nelma is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Nelma owns and operates a retail store, selling blankets, clothing and shoes in the local community. Nelma has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Nelma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Nelma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Nelma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Neang D. currently makes rattan furniture. He is 30 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, located about 250 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. His wife appears in the photo. He has only one child, who is enrolled in school. When Neang D. has made 15 sets of rattan, he sells them to his customers for profit. Generally, his valued clients need to order a few days or a week in advance. His wife helps him with the business, and they transport the finished products directly to customers' houses together. Recently, Neang D. has run out of raw materials from his stock supply, so he would like a Kiva loan in order to buy additional rattan to better meet his furniture orders.

loans.use: To buy additional rattan to meet furniture orders

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian A.  lives in Kamwokya Kifumbira, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school. Lilian has a business of selling new and second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for more than 10 years, and she works six days out of every week. Lillian sells her products in a retail shop. Lilian has requested for a loan of 1500000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO. She will use the loan to buy more bales of second-hand and new clothes. She also generates additional income through owning a bar. The main business challenges for Lilian include transportation and ever increasing prices of second-hand clothes. Her goal for her business is to start importing clothes herself. She joined MCDT to acquire additional capital. Lilian lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline P. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 30 years old. Evangeline is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling food and daily use products in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Evangeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fifth loan taken by Evangeline from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Vergenia

texts.en:
Vergenia N. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 47 years old. Vergenia is married and has seven grown children. To make a living, Vergenia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling food and daily use products in the local community. Vergenia has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Vergenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Vergenia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Vergenia is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the third loan taken by Vergenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Plasas Traders Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in Waterloo, a small town in Western Sierra Leone, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start up a branch. They have come to SMT, also a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit.

Isha K. (pictured on the right) is the leader of this group. She was born in a village called Yoni Bama in northern Sierra Leone. She is forty-five years old. Isha is married to a teacher and they have four children. 

Isha sells both fertilizer and vegetables at a place called Four Mile near Waterloo. She has fifteen years of experience in doing business. Isha will use her share of this loan to buy fertilizer and vegetables in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and vegetables in large quantity

loans.name: Arnaldo

texts.en:
Arnaldo D., a 47-year-old farmer from the town of Sto. Niño, has been planting and harvesting rice crops for 30 years. He says his harvest is used for family consumption and also sold to the market. His farm income helps his family with food, clothes and other needs.

Arnaldo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid his previous loan from CEVI, he is now requesting his seventh loan for 15000 PHP to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. Arnaldo plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma A. was born in 1954. She lives in Vardavank village, Kapan area, with her two sons. Emma works at Vardavank village administration as a librarian and at same time she and her sons are engaged in land cultivation and animal husbandry. They breed cows, pigs and chickens in their farm. Thanks to income from farming, Emma and her sons cover the majority of their family expenses and can develop their farm.  Emma is seeking a 400,000 AMD loan to buy a sow, a bull-calf and fodder for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy a sow, a bull-calf and fodder for pigs

loans.name: Arvie

texts.en:
Arvie A. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 31 years old. Arvie is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Arvie owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling personal products such as bags and pouches in the local community. Arvie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arvie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Arvie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Arvie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua S. sells "Fante kenkey" (fermented maize dough) at Abura. She is a widow and has six dependents. She has been producing "Fante kenkey" for sale for about ten years now. With the income she generates from her sales she makes sure that her dependents are well taken care off. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare "Fante kenkey" to distribute. She hopes to reinvest her new profits.

loans.use: buy more maize to prepare "Fante kenkey" to distribute

loans.name: God Na We Right Group

texts.en:
Yeanoh F. (pictured right) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born twenty-nine years ago in Bombali District, northern Sierra Leone, Yeanoh is married to a police officer and has one child.  For four years now, Yeanoh has been selling rice. Yeanoh will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business; she will buy bags of rice to add to her business.  

This is the first loan that Yeanoh and her group members have applied for a loan from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn G., from the village of Panalsalan, is 39 years old, married, and has two grown children. To make a living, Merlyn has been planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale for over six years, earning approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Merlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to invest in expanding the business, she is now requesting her ninth loan for 50000 PHP to pay for services to increase crop yield. Merlyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Beverlyn

texts.en:
Beverlyn S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Beverlyn raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Beverlyn works hard to keep her farm productive. She is hopeful to have an increase in her next harvest. 

Beverlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Beverlyn is requesting a new loan of 15.000 Philippines pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua C. is married and has three children. She has been through junior high school. Ekua sells toothbrushes, Pepsodent, body creams and other items by moving from one area to another at Abura. Her husband is an office clerk.  Ekua uses her income to help her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Ekua will use the loan to purchase more of her goods for sale.  Ekua plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. is 28 years old, married and has two children who are six and three years old, respectively. His wife runs a food kiosk, which is also a source of income for the family. Joseph has been in the transport business for two years with a monthly profit of Kshs.10,500. The business is situated in Gisambay, Kisumu where motorbike transport is very much in demand.

He is applying for his first loan of Kshs. 30,000 from KADET LTD to buy a new motorbike to improve his transport services. He desires to save the profit generated and be able to provide for his family.

In the future, Joseph desires to own a Matatu [P.S.V] (a larger vehicle used to transport several people at one time) through KADET loans. He is very hardworking and determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To buy  a new  motorbike

loans.name: If God Gree Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleased to present to you members of the “If God Gree” group from Waterloo, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are small-scale businesspeople seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Sulaiman S., pictured on the right. Sulaiman is aged thirty-five and was born in the village of Feredugu. He is married to a businesswoman and they have six children who are attending primary school.  

Sulaiman sells groundnuts/peanuts, palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), etc. Sulaiman has been running this business for many years now. He will use his share of this loan to buy groundnuts, palm oil, etc in large quantity to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy groundnuts, palm oil, etc in large quantity

loans.name: Ubaydullo

texts.ru: Кенчаев Убайдулло житель района Вахдат. Возраст 40 лет. Женат, отец 3 детей. Образование средне - специальное, шафер. По специальности не работает. На сегодняшний день он занимается ремеслом, то есть изготавливает деревянные изделия. В этой области уже 10 лет. Кредит берет для покупки древесины.
texts.en: Ubaydullo K. lives in the Vahdat district.  He is 40 years old, married and is a father of 3 children.  He has secondary-specialized education, as a driver.  He no longer works in that field.  Currently, Ubaydullo is involved in arts and crafts, i.e. he makes wooden creations.  He has been in this business for 10 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of wood.

loans.use: Purchase of wood

loans.name: Test We Sef Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Test We Self” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city.  They are requesting a loan of SLL 600,000 for each to enable them to further improve the size and quality of their respective businesses.

Pictured on the right is Zainab C. who is the leader of this group. Zainab was born in Devil Hole, on the outskirts of Freetown; she is aged thirty-seven. She is married to a policeman and the couple has four children – two of whom are in primary school and two in secondary school.

Zainab sells bread, biscuits, sweets, cigarettes, etc. She has been doing business for twenty years now. This loan will improve the size and quality of these entrepreneurs' businesses. Zainab will use her share of the loan to buy the above-named items in large number to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy bread, biscuits, sweets, cigarettes, etc.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Kate M. sells maize at Abura. Kate has senior high educational background. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a teacher. Her loan will be used to buy extra maize to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

In this picture, Kate is showing the maize kernels that she will be selling.

loans.use: buy extra maize to sell

loans.name: Gulnara's Group

texts.en:
Gulnara I. is the leader of the group. She is 43 and a widow. She has raised two sons and two daughters.  Fifteen years ago, Gulnara started to sell fruits and vegetables raised in her own garden.  In this way, she makes 9,750 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to purchase cattle for breeding. With money received from the loan, Gulnara wants to purchase apples in order to resell them at a higher price. In the future, she wants to build a house for her sons.
 
Aikukul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 47 and married. She has two daughters and two sons.  Aikukul is a teacher at school and her husband works in construction. Aikukul is also engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. 

Malike R., 45, is married. She has a son and three daughters. Her husband works in Russia and she is the director of the rural school. A year ago, with an initial investment of 25,000 soms, Malike started to breed cattle. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase four calves for breeding. 

Merinsahan M., 42, is married. She has a son and three daughters. Her husband works as a teacher of physical training at school. In order to earn money, Merinsahan sells toiletries in the market.  In this way, she earns 3,500 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more goods in order to increase the turnover of her business.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135   If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase apples

loans.name: Women Of Destiny Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Women Of Destiny” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 600,000 for each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Mariatu K. is the leader of this group. Mariatu is thirty-two years old, married to a farmer, and the couple have two children who are attending primary school. Mariatu sells hot water bottles, dishes, body sprays, slippers, etc. She has been doing this business for four years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy hot water bottles, dishes, body sprays, slippers, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase iron sheets to build a water business stall and open a retail shop

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long K. is 42 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. She earns a living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Long K. grows different kinds of crops, such as cabbages and cucumbers, which she harvests when they are ripe. Recently, her crop did not grow well because it was ravaged by insects. Because of that obstacle, she is seeking a loan to use for purchasing fertilizers to protect her crop.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to protect her crop

loans.name: God Is One Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the “God is One” group. They are small-scale businesspeople who are based in the small town of Waterloo, near the capital city Freetown. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mabinty S.. Mabinty is aged thirty-eight and was born in Freetown. She is married with three children. Her husband is a contractor and her children are attending school.  For seventeen years now, Mabinty has been selling used clothes. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying a bale of used clothes to add to her current stock.

loans.use: buy a bale of used clothes

loans.name: Bread Sellers Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Bread Sellers” group from Waterloo, a small town in Western Sierra Leone where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. They are petty businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Jariatu K.. Jariatu was born in Waterloo, twenty-six years ago. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver and her child is attending primary school.

Jariatu sells cooked rice, palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), uncooked 'foofoo' (food made out of cassava roots), etc. Jariatu has been a businesswoman for many years now. With her share of this loan, she will invest in her business by buying cooking ingredients, palm oil, 'foofoo', etc. in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients, palm oil, 'foofoo', etc.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi N. sells soap and plastic bowls at Abura. She is married and lives together with her two children. Her husband is a carpenter. She responsibly supports her husband in the upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more plastic bowls for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a chop bar (snack bar).

loans.use: buy more plastic bowls for resale

loans.name: Think For We Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Think For We” group from Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. These small-scale entrepreneurs have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Aminata K. (pictured in the left) is the leader of this group. The 44-year-old is married to a businessman and they have six children who are attending both primary and secondary schools. Aminata has been a businesswoman for fifteen years now; she sells palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil). With her share of this loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil to add to her business inventory

loans.name: James Gichuki

texts.en:
James is married; he and his wife have two children whom they support. He has been in the business of selling and repairing electrical items for four years with a good income. He was introduced to KADET Ltd. through existing clients; this will be his first loan from any MFI.

James' business is located in a densely populated area and he serves many customers who are mostly the residents of Dandora. With this loan he plans to buy more electronic tools to enhance his work. He plans to plough any extra profits back into the business to increase its stability.

James hopes to expand and have other branches, as he believes he is hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: The loan will be used to add more stock.

loans.name: Leh We Member Ii Group

texts.en:
Abubakarr S. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Abubakarr was born in Port Loko, a town in northern Sierra Leone, about  thirty-five years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple have two children who are attending primary school. For five years now, Abubakarr has been selling medicines.

This is first loan that Abubakarr and his group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Abubakarr will use his share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand his business; he will buy medicines wholesale to add to his current stock.

loans.use: Buy medicines wholesale to add to his current stock

loans.name: Tataisai Group

texts.en:
In the photo are the members of the “Tataisai” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mabinty B..  Mabinty is age thirty-four; she was born in a place called Walla. Currently, she is residing in Waterloo together with her husband and three children. Her husband is a tailor and her children are attending primary and secondary schools respectively. For ten years now,  Mabinty has been selling palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil) and rice. With this loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice to sell.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil and bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba M. is married and has seven dependents. Aba buys bags of charcoal and sells them in small quantities at Abura. Her husband is a farmer. Aba uses her income to help her husband in providing for the basic needs of the family. Aba will use the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to save to educate her dependents.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Habiba

texts.fr:
Madame Habiba T.  est une femme mariée, âgée de 34 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit  dans une famille polygame avec ses enfants, époux, coépouse et vit bien d’autres parents dans le quartier Sincina de la ville de Koutiala ( région de Sikasso ). 
Elle  n’a pas eu la chance de continuer les études primaires, raison pour laquelle elle a vite embrassé les activités génératrices depuis son jeune âge, auprès de sa maman. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle finit par opter pour la restauration depuis maintenant  7 ans. Très courageuse, elle est très bien connue dans le secteur dont sa notoriété est bonne, car reçoit beaucoup de clients par jour. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle et augmenter la taille de son activité, elle décida de rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux mois et elle est à son 1er prêt en individuel.  
Avec ce financement, Habiba  compte acheter,  5 sacs de  50  kg de haricot  pour les stocker, 5 cartons de spaghetti et des condiments alimentaires.
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des commerçants du grand marché de Koutiala et  effectue la vente de ses plats alimentaires dans son petit restaurant  à Koutiala ville à une clientèle mixte, au comptant. 
Elle espère  réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 65.000FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activités génératrices de revenus.    
 Elle  ambitionne solliciter un financement qui pourra lui permettre d’ouvrir un grand restaurant  dans la ville de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Ms. Habiba T. is a married woman, 34 years old and mother of three children. She lives in a polygamous family with her children, husband, co-wife and many other family members in the neighborhood of Sincina in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region).
She did not have the chance to complete her primary education, which is why she began working at a very young age, together with her mother.  After several different business attempts, that ended without success, seven years ago she opted for a restaurant business. Being very courageous, she is very well known in the industry, her reputation is very good and she has a large number of customers every day.
To satisfy her customers demand and increase the size of her business, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso two months ago and she requests her first individual loan.
With this loan, Habiba plans to buy 5 bags of 50 kg of beans each, 5 boxes of spaghetti and different condiments. She buys her supplies at the open market in Koutiala and she sells her food dishes in her small restaurant, always in Koutiala, in cash and to a mixed group of customers. 
She hopes to achieve an average profit of 65.000FCFA per month, that she would use to pay interests on her loan and she would invest the rest in income generating activities. Her ambition is to obtain a loan that will allow her to open a big restaurant in the town of Koutiala.

loans.use: Purchase food ingredients for a restaurant

loans.name: Naana

texts.en: Naana A. is into the sale of second-hand clothing. She is married and has four children. She has been in this business for five years now. Her husband is a driver. Naana uses her income she makes from her sales to feed the family as a way of helping her husband. Naana will use the loan to purchase additional bales of second-hand clothes for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Naana plans to save to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: purchase additional bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Aissa Kane

texts.fr:
Madame   AISSA KANE G. est âgée de 21 ans, célibataire  et mère  de 1 enfant.  Elle  vit chez ses parents dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Sokala de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
AISSA a abandonné l’école en classe de 9 ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour faire le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires,  des habits et chaussures. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle commença à évoluer seule en menant des activités  d’achat et de vente d’habits, de chaussures et de fournitures scolaires à l’approche des rentrées des classes. Elle mène cette  dernière activité depuis maintenant  3 ans et jouit d’une grande notoriété et réputation. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices à l’orée de la rentre scolaire, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 54 mois, après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels  tous correctement remboursés. 
Elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 2 cartons de cahiers de 100  pages. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako.
Madame   AISSA KANE G.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de nourrir sa mère et son fils  et de participer à des événements sociaux.   Son  ambition est de  construire  une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aissa Kane G. is 21 years old, single and mother to one child. She lives with her parents in a large traditional family in the Sokala district of Ségou (the Republic of Mali's fourth administrative region).

Aissa left school in ninth grade of elementary school (the Malian education system) to go into business with her mother who sold condiments, clothing and shoes. After several years' apprenticeship, she began to develop her own activities, selling clothing, shoes and school equipment just before the new school year. She has been carrying out this last activity for three years now and has a good reputation.

With the aim of expanding her business and making more money at the start of the school year, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso. She has been in relations with this institution for 54 months, having had three group loans and three individual loans, all of which have been repaid in full. She is now on her fourth individual loan which she plans on using to buy two cartons of 100-page exercise books. She gets her supplies in Bamako and sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of women and men. 

With this loan she is expecting to make a monthly profit of 40,000FCFA. This profit will allow her to feed her mother and her son and to take part in social events. Her ambition is to build a house.

loans.use: To buy school equipment

loans.name: Salimchon

texts.ru: Салимов Салимчон проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 26 лет. Женат, детей не имеет. Живет вместе с родителями. Высшего образования не имеет. Салимчон  предоставляет услугу, такси по маршруту Вахдат-Душанбе и Душанбе-Вахдат. В этой области уже 3 года. Кредит берет для приобретения автомашины.
texts.en: Salimchon S. lives in the Vahdat district.  He is 26 years old, married and has no children.  He lives together with his parents.  He does not have a higher education.  Salimchon provides a taxi service on the Vahdat-Dushanbe, Dushanbe-Vahdat route.  He has been in this business for 3 years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of a car.

loans.use: Purchase of a car

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina A. is married and has four children. She has been through senior high education. Sakina sells maize and smokes fish at Abura. Her husband is a driver. Sakina uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Sakina will use the loan to buy additional fresh fish to smoke for sale. Sakina plans to invest the new profits from her expanded business in her children’s education.

loans.use: buy additional fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr:
Monsieur IBRAHIMA B. est âgé de 35 ans, marié et père de 1 enfant.  Il vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
IBRAHIMA a abandonné l’école en classe de 7 ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour faire le commerce auprès de son grand frère qui vendait une boutique de quincaillerie. Après 10 ans d’apprentissage et fort de cette expérience, il jouit d’une grande notoriété et réputation. Alors il  décida d’évoluer de ses propres ailes  en menant comme activité le commerce générale et cela depuis 5 ans.
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, il a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Il  est   à son 1er  prêt individuel, qu’il  compte utiliser pour acheter, 20  rouleaux de tissus pour fauteuils, 2 cartons de colles, 10 boites de vernis et 1caisse de serrures. Il  s’approvisionne à Bamako auprès des grossistes.
Monsieur IBRAHIMA B. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de nourrir sa famille et de participer à des événements sociaux.  
Son ambition est de renforcer son commerce et  construire  une maison.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima B. is a 35-year-old married man and father of one child. He lives in a large, traditional family in the district of Darsalam, in Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali).

Ibrahima quit school in the 7th grade (Mali’s education system) to work alongside his brother in a hardware store. After learning the trade for ten years, and wanting to build on this experience and the great reputation he had achieved, he decided, five years ago, to work on his own and run a general store.

In order to boost his business and increase his profits, he turned to the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution. This is his first individual loan, which he intends to use to buy 20 rolls of upholstering fabric for chairs, 2 cartons of glue, 10 boxes of varnish and 1 case of locks. He gets his stocks from wholesalers in Bamako.

Ibrahima sells for cash or credit to a clientele consisting of men and women.

With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 100 000FCFA. This will allow him to feed his family and attend social events.

His goal his to strengthen his activities and build a house.

loans.use: To purchase various items

loans.name: Jumagul's Group

texts.en: Jumagul T. is the leader of the group. She is 21 and not married. After having finished school, she decided to support her mother by selling cotton-seed oil. Out of the business profits, she has managed to purchase a cow. In order to expand the business, Jumagul wants to purchase more oil (300 kg) for its further resale; with the rest of the money she wants to open a canteen. For this reason, she hopes to get a loan. In the future, the young girl is planning to open a foodstuffs shop in the village and to marry. Alisher E., 56, is married. His wife is an obstetrician-gynecologist by profession. The couple has three children. The sons work in Russia and the daughter is married and lives separately from her parents. Since 2000, Alisher has been working as a builder and besides that, he harvests rice. Out of his earnings, he has managed to arrange his children’s weddings. His loan purpose is to purchase hardware for building. In the future, his family is planning to build a house and to obtain a car. Aichurek K., 25, is married. Her spouse raises money by working as an information-science teacher in the local school. The couple brings up two small children. The family runs its own business, which consists of cultivating and harvesting rice. This year, it is expected to be a 5-ton crop of rice. Out of business profits, the family has managed to build a house. The loan's purpose is to purchase necessary equipment for harvesting (20 liters of petroleum-based fuels with the rest of the money for workers). The next season, Aichurek’s family is planning to widen the land for rice cultivating and to start breeding cattle. Soorbai S., 61, is married. His family has five children. The elder sons work in Bishkek, while the youngest one makes his bread by working as a teacher. His daughters are married and live separately from their parents. The family runs its own business: fruits and vegetables reselling, with the youngest son transporting the goods. The profits made it possible to purchase a lot and to build a house. The loan purpose is to purchase more vegetables and fruits for enlarging the assortment and increasing turnover. In the nearer future, Soorbai is planning to obtain a minibus for goods transportation. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase oil for resale

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa A. is married and has two children. She has received junior high education. Adjoa sells canned tomatoes and smoked fish at Abura. Adjoa will use the loan to acquire extra fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adjoa plans to help her husband educate their children.

loans.use: acquire extra fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Tolkun's Group

texts.en:
Tolkun B. is the leader of the group. She is 63, a widow. She has 2 sons, the eldest one works in District Department of Inner Affairs, the youngest is a builder by profession. The family is also engaged in cattle breeding; they are currently fattening two calves. From their profits they have managed to build a cow shed and to arrange one son’s wedding. The loan will be used to purchase roofing slate for the cow shed. In the future Tolkun is planning to increase their cattle stock and to make house repairs. 

Adolathon A., 64, married. Her spouse is already a pensioner. The big family consists of two sons and their wives. The eldest son is a college teacher, the younger son raises money by working as a guard in heat and power plant. Both of the wives are keeping house. From her profits Adolathon has managed to arrange her sons’ weddings and to fund her grandson's ceremony of circumcision. The loan purpose is to purchase livestock animals for fattening and breeding. In the future the family wants the elder son to live in a new house, they also want to finish building on their lot and to increase their cattle stock. 

Kenjehan S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 61 and married. Together with her husband, who is a pensioner, they have raised two sons, who now  live together with their parents and their wives and children. The elder son is a tractor operator, the younger raises money by selling fruits and vegetables, and both of wives sell greens. On the whole the main source of incoming is from cattle breeding. Out of total earnings Kenjehan has managed to arrange a son’s wedding. The loan's purpose is to purchase roofing slate. In the future the family is planning to increase cattle stock and to obtain a car.

Tursunali E., 71, is a widower. He has two sons who are already married. The children run their own business: reselling fruits and vegetables. Besides that, the family breeds cattle (3 livestock animals). Earnings have made it possible to make house repairs and to arrange a son’s wedding. The loan purpose is to purchase 3 livestock animals for fattening and breeding. In the future Tursunali wants to organize her grandsons' weddings, to make house repairs, and to develop the business.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing roofing slate for a cow shed

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca H. sells onions at Abura. Her husband is a mason. Rebecca has senior high level of education. She is married and has three children. She responsibly supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to expand her onion business. She plans on reinvesting her new revenue that is going to accrue as a result of the loan.

loans.use: expand her onion business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma N. lives in Kawempe, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members.    

Fatuma has a business of selling new women's clothes. She has been in this business for four years and she works six days out of every week. Fatuma sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.    

Fatuma has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more dresses, skirts and blouses. She also generates additional income through having a motorcycle for hire and rental rooms.

The main business challenges for Fatuma include seasonality and the ever-increasing price of clothes. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing clothes and to build more rental rooms.   

Fatuma lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more blouses, skirts and dresses

loans.name: Roza's Group

texts.en:
Roza J., 44 and divorced, is the leader of this group. Both of her sons make their livelihood by working in Russia. Roza's main source of income is cattle breeding, a business she started five years ago with two sheep and a calf. From the proceeds she has managed to organize her son’s wedding. Roza is now requesting a loan to purchase sheep for fattening and breeding, and in the future she is planning to arrange her second son’s wedding, build a new house, and acquire grazing land for cattle.

Anarhon S. is the treasurer of the group. She is a 45-year-old married mother of three children, the eldest of whom works in Russia, while the other two are students. The family's business is cattle breeding, and they currently have two milk cows and two calves. Their business earnings have enabled them to provide an education for their children and build a house. The loan will allow for the purchase of a cow for fattening, and in future Anarhon wants to increase their cattle stock and build a house for her sons.

Bakytbek A. is a 44-year-old married father of three sons, all students, and a daughter who works with her mother in Russia. The main family business is cattle breeding, a business they started three years ago with only one calf. From subsequent profits the family has managed to build a temporary house. The loan's purpose is to purchase feed for cattle, and in the future Bakytbek is planning to increase his cattle stock, obtain a car, and give a proper education to his children.

Asilbek A., 37 and married to a farmer, is the father of three children, two of whom are students, while the youngest is a toddler. The family is engaged in cattle breeding and they currently have a cow, a calf, and ten sheep. Earnings have enabled them to purchase a tractor for ploughing. The loan's purpose is to buy spare parts for the tractor, and in the future Asilbek is planning to increase his cattle stock and build a house for his son.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
