MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Norly

texts.en:
This is Norly N., a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is blessed with a child, a young adult who is currently enrolled in high school. By the grace of God, Norly has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to continue sending her child all the way through college.

Norly operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies in at a wholesale price and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Norly dreams to be able to move to another city with more expansion opportunities for her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Adiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame Adiaratou Samaké est une femme mariée de 32 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit  dans une famille monogame avec ses enfants chez son époux dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni.
Après des études secondaires sanctionnées par un diplôme d’enseignant, elle est restée pendant des années sans emploi. Ainsi elle décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et vente de pagnes. Elle a appris cette activité auprès de son ami. Avec une expérience de 4 ans elle maitrise son activité. 
Pour obtenir un fond de roulement consistant, elle décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des pagnes. 
Elle est à sa première expérience avec l’institution. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de république du Mali). Sa clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes. La vente se fait  d’une façon ambulante dans les différents quartiers  de la ville de Bougouni, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit payable mensuellement ou journalièrement.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000FCFA. Elle envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adiaratou Samaké is a 32 year old married woman. She is the mother of 2 children and lives in a monogamous family with her children and husband in the Torakabougou district of Bougouni.

After finishing her secondary studies with a teaching diploma, she remained unemployed during several years. She thus decided to start income-generating activities, notably buying and selling “pagnes” (traditional brightly-colored fabric). She learned this business alongside her friend. With 4 years of experience, she has a good command of her business. 

In order to have a substantial working capital, she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso to purchase “pagnes”. 

This is her first experience with the institution. She gets her supplies from Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). Her customer-base is mainly composed of women. She sells door-to-door in the different districts of the town of Bougouni, accepting cash and sometimes credit, payable monthly or daily.
She plans to make a monthly profit of 30,000 CFA Francs. She is considering expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase "pagnes" (traditional brightly-colored fabric)

loans.name: Altyn's Group

texts.en:
Altyn C. is the group’s leader. She is 42 and married. Her family has two children: the daughter is a student, and the son earns money by working as a bartender. Today Altyn is engaged in her own business: she is trading in neighboring villages. Fifteen years ago, because she lives near the road, she began to sell foodstuffs, petroleum, etc. With her profits she has managed to increase her stock of cattle. Altyn hopes to put her loan into developing her business. In the future she intends to build a house on a lot in Bishkek. Also, she wants to help indigent families.

Mairamkul A., 40, is married. Her spouse makes his living by working as a school watchman. The family has three children: the eldest daughter is a seamstress, and the other two daughters are at school. The main source of income is from harvesting potatoes. She plans to use her loan for supplies and necessities. In the future, the family wants to increase their stock of cattle.

Jumabubu T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 56 and married. Her husband is a pensioner. The couple has nine children, all of whom, except the youngest one, live separately from their parents. The family business consists of cattle breeding and sales. Out of the profits they have managed to arrange their children’s weddings. The purpose of the loan is to purchase livestock. In the future Jumabubu intents to increase their stock of cattle and to improve her family's wealth.

Chynara A., 22, is married. She lives together with her parents. Her mother raises money by making national hardware. As well as helping her mother, Chynara works in Bishkek (her salary is 5000 soms per month). The purpose of the loan is to pay for her study (Chynara studies by correspondence). In the future she is planning to graduate from university and find a job in order to support her parents.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs

loans.name: Bubuajar's Group

texts.en:
Bubuajar A. is the leader of the group. She is 57 and married. Her family has six children: two daughters are in Russia, the son and his father work in a voluntary society of army, aviation and fleet assistance, one of the daughters is a seamstress, one is a ticket collector, and the other is a manager. Moreover, the family is engaged in cattle breeding. Out of their total profits they have managed to build a house, to arrange the daughters’ weddings, and to prepare their dowries. In order to purchase a cow, the family needs to get a loan. In the future Bubuajar is planning to finish building their house, to obtain a car, and to provide education for her grandchildren.

Jumakan B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. Her family has four children: the eldest daughter works in Bishkek City, the son earns money by working at a filling station, one daughter is a student, and the youngest child is at home. The family wants to get a loan to use for their necessities. In the future Jumakan wants to arrange her son’s wedding, to prepare a dowry for her daughter, to cultivate potatoes, and to obtain a car.

Asel D., 30, is married. Together with her husband, she is raising three daughters, all of whom are of preschool age. The purpose of the loan is to purchase coal. In the future Asel is planning to provide proper education for her children, to build a big house, and to purchase a car.

Nazgul S., 32, is married. Her family is raising three children, all of whom are at school. The main source of income is from cattle breeding. Out of their profits over the course of five years they have managed to purchase a car. The purpose of the loan is to buy two animals. In the future Nazgul wishes to finish building their house and to obtain a new car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah K. lives in Kitawuluzi, a neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has eight children, three of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren). Hadjah has a business selling jerrycans of local gin and crates of beer. She has been in this business for four years, and she works seven days out of every week. Hadjah sells her products from home, as a wholesale operation. Hadjah has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of local gin. She also generates additional income through selling piped water.

Hadjah's main business challenges include transportation and thieves. Her goals for her business are to own permanent business premises and to educate her children to the university level. Hadjah lives in a house that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gin and crates of beer

loans.name: Joseph Mbaja

texts.en:
Joseph Mbaja O. is 39 years old and married to Millicent Ademo. They have two children, namely Jane Kamidi, 14 years old, and Calvine Asene, 10 years old. He has been running a retail kiosk in Mahanga, Vihiga, for 15 years and earns a profit margin of Kshs.15,000.

He has no history with any other MFI and he is applying for his second loan of Kshs. 30,000 from KADET LTD, to add more stock of assorted items like sugar, salt, small packets of omo, etc. for the business, to allow him to give better service to his customers. He plans to use the anticipated profit to increase his savings with KADET and be able to provide basic needs for his family.

In the future, Joseph hopes to expand his business and establish a wholesale outlet.

loans.use: To add more stock of assorted items like sugar, salt, small packets of omo, etc.

loans.name: Taalaibubu's Group

texts.en:
Taalaibubu K. is the leader of the group. She is 58 and married. The family has three children: the son works in Kara-keche, growing potatoes on the plantation. Currently Taalaibubu works in housing administration. The family needs to get a loan in order to purchase livestock for fattening and breeding. In the future the family wants to increase their cattle stocks.

Kymbatbubu S., 51 and a widow, is the treasurer of the group. She has to take care of her two daughters by herself. The older one is divorced and works in Bishkek City, and the younger daughter lives with her mother. Kymbatbubu is engaged in cattle breeding, and is fattening two sheep. During the years of working hard she has managed to increase her cattle stock. The purpose of the loan is to purchase more cattle. In the future Kymbatbubu wants to increase her cattle stock, to set up her daughters, and to improve the family's wealth.

Turgunbek B., 52, is married. Together with his spouse, who is a housewife, he is raising five children. Two of their daughters are married, and the rest go to school. The family enlarges its budget by being engaged in cattle breeding, and by now they are fattening five sheep. The purpose of the loan is to purchase more cattle. In the future Turgunbek is planning to increase his cattle stock and to improve his family's welfare.

Byubyusara M., 48, is married. Her spouse is a pensioner. The family has five children: the eldest daughter is a student, and the rest are in school. The main source of income is cattle breeding, and by now they are fattening five sheep. Over the last three years, the family has managed to increase their cattle stocks. The purpose of the loan is to purchase more cattle. In the future Byubyusara is planning to increase their stock of cattle, to arrange her daughter’s wedding, and to improve the family's wealth.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for breeding

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
This is Jasmin P., 46, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Restituto P., a driver, and mother to four children. By the grace of God, Jasmin has managed to pay for her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continue to send all of them all the way through college.

Jasmin oversees operations of their jeepney (see footnote) transportation business. They have long (20-22 person capacity) and short(14-16 person capacity) jeepneys, all of which are paying boundary (daily quota) each day. Jasmin’s husband also drives one of the jeepneys. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 35,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan for repair and other needs of the jeepneys. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Jasmin dreams of being able to buy another jeepney soon. She also dreams that her children will finish their education. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

-Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater "jeepney", open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for everyday travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly the Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: for repair and other needs of the jeepneys (public transport buses)

loans.name: Burulkan's Group

texts.en:
Burulkan M. is the leader of this group. She is 74 and a widow. She has one son. Burulkan is a pensioner; her pension benefit is 3500 soms per month. Over 4 years she has managed to build a temporary house. She needs to get a loan in order to pay her granddaughter's university study. She cherishes a hope to see her children happy.

Asel M. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and married. Together with her spouse, who is a farmer, they are raising three children; their sons are schoolboys and their daughter goes to kindergarten. 15 years ago, the head of the family privatized a building, which later was reshaped into a café. Now this café is the main source of family income. Out of the profits they have managed to purchase a house. The family hopes to get a loan in order to buy some café implements. In future Asel is planning to develop the business further. 

Berdibek J., 49, married. His wife earns her living by working in a shop as a saleswoman (she earns 2500 soms per month). The couple has 2 sons; both of them are schoolboys. Berdibek supports his family by working as a watchman at a petroleum station, besides he is an MIA pensioner, and on the basis of this fact gets a pension benefit. His total earnings are about 10,000 soms per month. During 5 years of working hard, the family has managed to increase their herd of cattle. The loan purpose is to purchase cattle for fattening. In future Berdibek is planning to buy a house and a car.

Sagynbek I. U., 54, is married. Together with his wife he runs their own family business. As his wife has vocational education, they rented premises and opened a pharmacy. I.’s duty is helping his wife to transport medicines. The family wants to use the loan money for commodity circulation. In future they are planning to purchase a car and to expand the business even more.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for the granddaughter's education at university

loans.name: Abari Hamadoun

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abari Hamadoun Boiré est un homme marié de 28 ans et père de 3 enfants, qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une famille nucléaire  au quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de  Bougouni.
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, dés son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus. Avant qu’il ne commence cette activité de vente d’une boutique, il était vendeur de pain dans une boulangerie de la place pendant des années. C’est partir de cette activité qu’il a  économiser pour pour ouvrir une boutique. Avec une expérience de plus de 7 ans il maîtrise cette activité qu’il a appris auprès de son ami. Sa boutique est située dans le quartier de Torakabougou.
Afin de renforcer son activité, il décide d’intégrer Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier qui sera utilisé pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique. Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni. Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50.000FCFA qui sera essentiellement utilisé pour agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mister Abari Hamadoun Boiré is a 28 year-old married man with three children. He lives with his wife and children as a nuclear family in the Heremakono North neighborhood of the town of Bougouni.
As he did not attend modern school, he embarked on revenue-generating activities from the youngest age. Before launching his sales activity with this store, he worked as a bread salesman in a local bakery for years. It is from this activity that he saved enough to open his own shop. With over seven years of experience, he has mastered his trade, which he learned from a friend. His store is located in the Torakabougou neighborhood.
He decided to join Soro Yiriwaso to strengthen his activity. This is his first loan with them, and it will be used to purchase various articles for the store. He gets his supplies in Bougouni. His customer base is made from the local population.
He is planning on a monthly benefit of 50,000 CFA francs, which will mostly be used to expand his store.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for the store

loans.name: Flavia

texts.en:
Flavia N. lives in Kawempe, a neighbourhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (niece and nephew).   

 Flavia has a business selling bananas.  She has been in this business for 9 years and she works 7 days out of every week. Flavia   sells her products at the market, wholesale and retail.    Flavia has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas.     

The main business challenges for Flavia include transportation, thieves and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van to ease transportation costs and also educating her children up to university.   Flavia lives in a home that she owns; she doesn't have access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Aygul

texts.en:
Aygul O. is 39 years old, married, and has three children.  Since childhood, Aygul has been fond of sewing and her dream of becoming a designer led her to get a job as a seamstress at the state knitted goods factory. She gained wide experience in this activity and became a team leader of a sewing workshop.   In 1996, within the period of breakdown in the Soviet Union, she lost her job.  Aygul and her family went through some difficult times with little money and no house, but they did not give up and made every effort to improve their living conditions. Aygul, being a very persistent and hardworking woman, borrowed a sum of 8,000 KGS and began her business in clothes selling. Her start as an entrepreneur was successful due to her strong efforts. She managed to rent a sales point at the local market and raise her floating capital to 60,000 KGS. Her activity was marked by her designer's approach and personal advice to every client. 

In 2009, in order to broaden her business, Aygul obtained her first loan of 20,000 KGS from Bai Tushum and Partners, which was repaid without any delays. Now  Aygul is requesting a loan of 40,000 KGS to expand the range of products in her shop. She hopes that the loan will help her increase revenue. In the future, Aygul wants to buy a car for her  family.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that leads to increased employment and meets the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Rec Isl Pri Rokel Ii Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the REC Rokel Primary School II, in Waterloo small town, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. This school was founded in September 1985. It is staffed with 21 teachers and 600 pupils.

These hard-working and dedicated teachers have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 8,900,000. With the help of this loan, these teachers can embark on some meaningful projects that their mere salaries alone cannot do. Some of them will use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, others to buy house building materials, some a piece of land, some pay school fees for their children, and some of them will invest the loan in business. 

Edward O.K. C. is the leader of this group of teachers. Edward is married to a businesswoman and they have seven children. Four of the children are attending primary school and two are in secondary school. Edward has been in the teaching profession for 29 years now. Edward has applied for a SLL 1,500,000 loan in order to pay school fees and other school related charges for his children.

loans.use: To pay school fees and other school related charges for his children

loans.name: Rec Jui Lower Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the REC Jui Primary School, in Waterloo small town, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. This school was built by the Rural Education Committee to educate the children of Jui community. 

These hard-working and dedicated teachers have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 9,500,000. With the help of this loan, these teachers can embark on some meaningful projects that their mere salaries alone cannot do. Some of them will use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, others to buy house-building materials, some a piece of land, some to pay school fees for their children, and some of them will invest the loan in business. 

Samuel A. T. is the leader of this group of teachers. Born in the village of Mogereh, Samuel today resides in Waterloo together with his wife and three children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending both primary and secondary schools, respectively. Samuel is requesting this loan in order to buy house building materials and to pay school fees for his children.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy house-building materials and pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Abdirasul

texts.en:
Abdirasul K. is a married father of 4 children. He grows wheat, watermelons, onions, rice, and carrots, which he plants once a year. His wife is a teacher in a local school. To help meet the hard physical labor of his farming work his children work with him. Farming is the main source of earning income to sustain this family’s living conditions. Abdirasul is applying for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. This fund will ensure the economic prosperity of this friendly family.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Karimjon

texts.en:
Karimjon is married with two children. He lives in Khujand and works as a taxi driver. He has been in this business for 7 years. One of the most outstanding characteristics of his venture has been its stability and consistent growth. Karimjon is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD to cover expenses connected with repairing his car. Then he will be able to provide good and qualitative service, and with this increase his profit. We believe his drive for success and increased profits will be the best motivation for prompt loan repayment and further development of his business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing his car.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
This is Helen L., 38, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Macario L., a vendor, and is the mother of four children, two of whom are already working, while the others are still in school. By the grace of God, Helen has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send the rest of her children all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Helen, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Helen operates a fish stall. Fish is bought fresh from nearby ports and piers, packed in ice and then brought to the local markets. Helen and her husband clean, gut and chop fish as per customer orders. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy fish for their everyday inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Helen dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes that her family can migrate and work in other countries in the near future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy fish for their everyday inventory.

loans.name: Muborak

texts.en:
Muborak is married with three children. She owns a small business that sells clothing at the central market in Khujand and has been in this business for 7 years. Muborak has always offered high quality products and excellent client service. She has many repeat clients that make her business a success. Muborak has an active life that encourages her business neighbors and friends. She has used micro-loans before and found them very helpful. This time, Muborak would like to borrow $1,000 USD to increase her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and receive additional income to help her son pay for college.

loans.use: To purchase new goods for selling in order to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret O. is 54 years old and is married to John O., who runs a butchery that adds to the income for the family. They have three children aged 28, 23 and 15. Margaret cooks chapattis and chips which she sells to her customers, who are mostly residents of Katito and passersby. Her monthly income from this business is Kshs. 6,000.

She is applying for a second loan of Kshs.10,000 from KADET LTD after paying her first loan successfully, and she plans to buy stock of wheat flour, cooking oil, and English potatoes for making French fries locally known as chips. The profit she gets from the proceeds of this loan she plans to save and pay school fees for her last born child who is joining form one next year.

Margaret hopes to grow her business and support her family effectively. She is very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more stock of wheat flour, cooking oil, and English potatoes.

loans.name: Mehri

texts.en:
Mehri is married with two children. She is an aspiring entrepreneur from Khujand, Tajikistan. Mehri runs a business of selling office supplies and other household items in the central marketplace. Her enterprise is well-known for a flexible discount system she offers to her customers. Mehri has always wanted to be self-employed. Her parents have been very supportive of the idea, which is why she ventured to make her dream come true about 13 years ago. Mehri wants to keep her enterprise running to be able to provide for her family and support her elderly parents, too. She has many bright ideas she is hoping to implement along the way. Mehri is a lively optimist and tries to mirror that attitude in her work as well. She is requesting a loan of $2,000 USD and is hoping to repay the loan without any delinquencies. One of her personal wishes is to finish remodeling her private house to make it a more comfortable place to live.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
Their education is the most important inheritance Marhabo and her husband can give to their three dear children. They are both very responsible parents and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school – an opportunity they never had due to poor finances. This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married, and with the unconditional help of her husband she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, she now finds herself with more expenditures and she would like a loan in order to increase their capital by increasing their number of cattle. Marhabo and her family are waiting for your quick response.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.en:
Shahnoza is an entrepreneur who runs a business selling clothing for kids. She has been in this business for three years. Shahnoza has loyal customers who come to buy from her because they trust the quality of her inventory and enjoy her friendly and respectful service. She has used micro loans in the past and found them very instrumental in her business. This time Shahnoza is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD to increase the assortment of her inventory. She would like to purchase additional clothing for the upcoming cold weather so that she can increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Rukhsora

texts.en:
Rukhsora K. is a widow and the mother of 3 children. She sells the national bread “lepeshka” in the local marketplace of Kurgantyube, where she lives with her family of three. She started working in the market as a salesperson. Rukhsora has been in this sphere of trade for 11 years. Currently, she is planning to start her own bakery business with the help of her adult children. That is the reason that she asked for a loan of $1,500 USD. Rukhsora has gained much experience working in the sphere of commerce as a salesperson at first. Today she is happy to be self-employed and see her small enterprise grow and become more and more stable. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase flour wholesale for baking the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom K. is 53 years old. She is married with three children. With the purpose of helping her husband to support the family, Dilorom is running her own business. She sells jewelry and has been in this business for more than 7 years. Today, Dilorom is requesting $3,000 US Dollars. She is planning to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets, and chains in order to enlarge the range of goods for sale. This is the eighth loan for Dilorom and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan as she did with her previous loans.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
