loans.name: Nyamtseren

texts.en: Nyamtseren T. is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two adult daughters in Hovd province of Mongolia. His daughters, ages 21 and 20, both attend university. In 2000, he began his business of selling clothes, with help of his wife, and has since managed to increase his working capital. His earnings have enabled him to purchase an apartment for his family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Nyamtseren hopes to continue expanding his business and save money for his children's future education. He is an honest and well disciplined man. He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase new season's clothes for the upcoming autumn months in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase new season's clothes.

loans.name: Shafiqan's Group

texts.en:
Shafiqan lives in a small city in Pakistan called Pakpattan. Pakpattan is located in Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its sugar production. Shafiqan is a 56 year old housewife. She prefers to spend her time at home by managing the household chores and taking care of her family. She has given birth to 2 sons. Both are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education.  She is a widow and lives with her brother. Her brother has a scrap business. He has been in this business for over seven years. He also contributes a part of his income to his family to support them financially. 

Shafiqan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her brother’s business. With the loan amount he will buy scrap in bulk quantities to minimize the cost of purchasing and to fulfill larger orders on time. Shafiqan is hopeful that her brother will make good profits from his business after making this investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She is hopeful that it will bring good changes to her family’s life and that their living standard will become better. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Shafiqan”.

loans.use: To buy scrap in bulk quantities for scrap business.

loans.name: Shukran's Group

texts.en:
Shukran is a housewife. She stays at home and does her household responsibilities and takes care of her family. She has given birth to 2 sons: one of them operates a donkey cart and the other is a daily wage labor. Shukran and her husband, G. M., live in a small city in Pakistan called Pakpattan, it is located in Punjab and known for its sugar production. They own a 3 room brick house in the area named 14SP and live in it with their family. Her husband is a private entrepreneur and deals with fertilizers and seed-selling business. He has been in this business for the past seven years. He sells his products to farmers particularly and earns a good profit. 

Shukran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for the betterment of her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy fertilizer and seeds in bulk. The bulk products will enable him to meet the urgent orders on time and to earn good profit on it. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year she has proven herself as a responsible client who never missed any meetings and paid her installments on time. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands in Shukran”.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds in bulk quantities for reselling.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Mrs. Svay H., 60, is a widowed mother who lives in the Kompong Tom Province. She is the mother of three kids, two are married and one is single. All three of her children are employed in various jobs. Her husband died of senility years ago. Mrs. Svay H. wakes up early in the morning in order to cook the rice soup for selling, and most of her customers are people who live near her house. The main source of income in her family comes from her daughter who sells groceries in front of her house. Presently, Svay H.’s daughter is lacking some money for purchasing more grocery items. Mrs. Svay H. hopes to encourage her daughter in the business, but she has no cash to make that possible. So, Mrs. Svay H. would like to borrow some funds for her daughter to purchase a larger amount of grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a larger amount of grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Mastura's Group

texts.en:
Mastura Z. is the leader of the group. She is 61 years old and married. Her spouse is working as a watchman in an industrial complex. The couple has four children: the elder son raises money by working as a builder, the daughter works as a nurse in a polyclinic, the youngest son currently works in Russia. Besides this, the family is engaged in cattle breeding. At this point, 2 cows and 7 livestock animals are being fattened. Out of profits, Mastura has managed to arrange her children’s weddings. Her loan purpose is to purchase 6 sheep for fattening and resale. In the future the family is aiming to create a mini-farm. In addition, Mastura wants to sell products.

Zinat P., 58, is married. She is the treasurer of the group. Her family has four children. Her daughters are married and live separately from parents. Her sons work in Russia. Zinat, together with her spouse, a farmer, runs their business of cattle breeding. Out of the earnings, the family has managed to organize the children’s weddings. In order to obtain a cow for fattening and breeding, the family is planning to get a loan. In the future they want to create their own mini-farm.

Gulshayir K., 30, is married. Together with her husband, who supports the family by working as a private builder, she has a daughter. 4 years ago, when Gulshayir lived with her parents, she used to run her business of reselling dairy products. With the business, she earned money to obtain furniture. The loan purpose is to purchase dairy products (100 kg) for further resale. In the future, the family intends to open a shop for foodstuff selling.   

Nargiza D., 24, is divorced. She makes her icome by cattle breeding. Now, with the help of her parents, she fattens up 2 bulls. Her loan purpose is to purchase 3 sheep in order to expand the business. In the future Nargiza wishes to create a mini-farm and to marry successfully.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase six sheep.

loans.name: Yryskan's Group

texts.en:
Yryskan S. is the leader of the group. She is a 60 year old widow. She has 2 sons: the eldest is engaged in trade in Bishkek, the youngest one is a farmer. The family enriches their budget by cattle breeding and selling dairy products. During the years of working they have managed to build a two-room house. The loan purpose is to purchase a color TV-set. In the future Yryskan is planning to increase her cattle stock.

Ainura A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and married. Her husband is currently working in Russia. Temporarily she has to take care of 4 children by herself, the elder are schoolboys, the youngest daughter goes to kindergarten. The family makes their living by cattle breeding. They have a milking cow and 2 heifers. Out of their profits they have managed to make house repairs. In order to purchase a lot for further house building, Ainura hopes to get a loan. In the future she intends to install gates and a fence and then to give university education to the children. 

Kyzdarhan T., 47, is married. Her husband raises money by repairing highways. The couple has 3 children: the eldest son works in Russia, the rest are school students. Since 1995, the family has been engaged in cattle breeding. They had started from fattening 9 sheep and a cow and now they have 2 cows with a calf and 4 sheep. This business made it possible to obtain a TV-set. In order to plow up land, the family needs to get a loan. In the future Kyzdarhan is planning to arrange her son’s wedding, to give her children an education and to build a house.

Uulhan JusumA., 60, is married. Her husband is a pensioner. The couple has 4 children: the daughters are married, the sons are farmers. The main family source of incoming is cotton cultivating. Out of the business profits they have managed to increase their cattle stock. Uulhan hopes to get a loan in order to purchase wheat seeds. In the future she is planning to build a summer kitchen and to buy furniture.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a TV.

loans.name: Maharamhon's Group

texts.en:
Maharamhon A. is the leader of the group. She is 40, and married. She has 4 children: the son earns money by working as a butcher, the daughter studies tailoring, the other 2 are students. The head of the family makes his income by cattle breeding. Currently he is fattening 4 cows. For the past 20 years he has been selling meat. Out of the business profits the family was able to make house repairs. This loan purpose is to purchase golden accessories for their daughter, due to her wedding. In the future Maharamhon is planning to arrange her daughter’s wedding and to purchase more cattle for fattening. 

Mubarak A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36, and married. She has to bring up 3 children alone because of husband is currently working in Russia. The family gets profits from cattle breeding. Currently they have 2 cows. Out of their earnings it was possible to build a five-room house. In order to obtain a calf, Mubarak wants to get a loan. In future she is planning to give her children a university education and to increase cattle stock.

Dilfuzahon M., 36, is married. Together with her husband, a farmer, she has 3 children. The eldest daughter helps her parents, and younger two are students. The family has their own business of cultivating (on the area of 0,25 hectares) and selling onions. Out of profits they have managed to obtain furniture. The loan purpose is to purchase a washing-machine. In the future Dilfuzahon is aiming to arrange her daughter’s wedding, to give her children a university education and to buy a car. 

Karimberdi K., 42, is married. He and his wife, a farmer, are raising three children, two of them are students. The family is engaged in cattle breeding. They are currently fattening a cow and a calf. Out of their earnings they have managed to purchase a TV-set. The loan purpose is to obtain sheep for further fattening and breeding. In the future Karimberdi hopes to increase his cattle stock and then to purchase a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase golden accessories for the daughter due to her wedding.

loans.name: Andres

texts.en:
Andres G. is from the town of Plaridel. He is 68 years old. Andres is separated and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Andres owns & operates a fishing business, harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Andres has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Andres joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Andres has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Andres is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks & nets. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Andres from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment, including hooks & nets.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina S. is very positive and energetic woman. She lives in Belovodskoe village, 54, married and has three grown children. She graduated from agricultural college and still works as a veterinarian. Her husband worked as a driver, but his wage was very low and didn’t cover all expenses.

In order to support the family and find an additional means of subsistence for her children, Galina decided to breed animals. In 1995, using her initial capital of 5,000 Kyrgyz Soms (KGS), she started to breed rabbits and pigs, which became a profitable activity. With the revenues, Galina was able to pay for education for her children and now her elder daughter works as a cheese maker at the dairy factory, the second daughter is seamstress, and the younger son is a student at technical college.

Her tireless personality and hardworking activities lead Galina to engage in poultry farming and today her farm has turkeys, ducks and chicken. This has allowed her to buy a sewing machine for her daughter.  Now Galina plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to buy eight pigs and forage for her livestock. In future, Galina wants to see her son get married and is looking forward having grandchildren one day.

About Bai-Tushum
Bai-Tushum uses its funding from Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. It is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita T. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 51 years old, widowed and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Carmelita makes and sells food. Selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community is her main source of income. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2005, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services with the hope of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has taken out 11 loans from PMPC, and successfully her previous loan of 20,000 PHP. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory, and as working capital for a food business

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean M. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 56 years old and married. She has five children; the eldest is 32 and the youngest is 23 years old. To make a living, Jean plants and harvests rice for sale. With her income from her business, Jean also supports her grandchildren, especially in their education. 

Jean joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jean is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Jenneby

texts.en:
Jenneby P. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 54 years old. Jenneby is married and has ten children. Her eldest child is 35 years old and the younger ones still go to school. To make a living, Jenneby plants and harvests rice. She also plants vegetables like eggplant. She says her farm helps a lot in paying for her children's education.

Jenneby joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita D. C. is from the village of Divisoria Santiago. She is 46 years old. Teresita is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she makes and sells cooked foods in the local community. Aside from that she also sells a variety of produce, such as fruits and vegetables. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $82 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Teresita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 13th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly  farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Luwayo Women's Group 2-Lugazi

texts.en:
K. Lawrence belongs to the Luwayo Women’s group-Lugazi. Lawrence traces his beginnings in business to the time when he was a wholesale seller. Savings from this business enabled him to start his taxi business. It was about 12 years ago when he took root in his taxi driving business in Luwayo-Lugazi. Lawrence also raises poultry and does animal husbandry. 100,000 shillings is what he makes in a week. 

Lawrence is happily married with 8 kids. With this loan he says he wants to revamp his taxi business. By improving his operations through repairs, safety checks, and maintainence, he says he will be able to travel longer distances than before. This will earn him greater profits. In the event of this happening he says he will buy another car.

loans.use: The expansion of his  operations through repairs,checks and maintainence on his taxi

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida C. is from the village of Divisoria, Santiago. She is 55 years old. Zenaida is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling health & medicinal products in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther K. is 41 years old and married to Antony Mwangi. They have two children. One daughter, Jenipher, is 20 years old and in college. They live in Kakamega town.

Esther sells used clothes in the open air market. She has been running this business for the last five years and is applying for her first loan. She intends to use the money to buy several bails of used clothes to add to her stock. She hopes to use the profits made to pay school fees for her children.

Her hope and dream is to open up a boutique in the future and start selling ready made clothes.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell

loans.name: Jopeth Jay

texts.en:
Jopeth Jay L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 21 years old. He raises pigs to earn a living. He had to stop going to school because of financial difficulties in his family. Now he is happy to say that because of his business raising pigs, he is able to continue his college education. He also started farming. He plants and harvests rice crops for sale. He says it is a challenge to manage work and school time but he is determined to finish college and find a job so he can continue to help his family.

Jopeth Jay joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jopeth Jay has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jopeth Jay is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP (Philippine pesos) which will be used to purchase farm supplies, four piglets, and to repair his pig pen. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for his tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase four piglets and repair his pig pen

loans.name: Luwayo Women's Group 1 - Lugazi

texts.en:
Forty-five-year-old Mary N. is with the Luwayo Women’s Group - Lugazi. Eight years is the time she has been operating a retail business in Luwayo-Lugazi. It is with capital from alcohol sales that she was able to begin this business. She has a cross-section of clients who frequent her retail shop, most of them being tenants in the nearby housing estates. 

Mary is married with seven kids. They are all in school. With this loan, she wants to buy in bulk more retail items such as sugar, maize flour, air time, soap, edibles, etc. She says she will resell them so that she can continue building her profit base.

loans.use: The purchase in bulk of more retail goodies such as sugar, maize flour, air time,etc., for resale

loans.name: Allan

texts.en: Allan J., 36 and married to Grace Cheche, is the father of three children aged 10, 7, and 5 years old.  For the past two years, Allan has owned and operated a mobile phone accessories business in Kakamega town.  Introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who is also a client of the organization, Alan is now applying for his first loan to buy phone accessories such as batteries, chargers, etc. His dream is to open up an electronics shop in the future as his business expands.

loans.use: To buy phone chargers and batteries to add to his stock

In 2010, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan for 5000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man and the father of three school-aged children. Since 2001, he has owned a car repair shop that specializes in vehicle bodies. He has been repairing cars for the past 25 years. His business income is vital for his wife and children. He works hard to earn a good profit in order to pay school fees. Since starting his business, he has worked hard to develop it, and he has many more customers now. Today, he is asking to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional tools for his business. In the future, he is planning to open a larger store where he can also sell spare car parts.

loans.use: To purchase tools

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline M. is 26 years old and married to Martin Simiyu. They have a son named Kevin who is four years old. He is in baby class. They live in Lugulu area on the outskirts of Kakamega town.

Caroline owns a salon. She is applying for her first loan to purchase hair chemicals and rollers. She has been running the salon for the past two years. Her monthly income is 6,000 KES. 

She hopes to open a boutique also, in order to earn extra profits.

loans.use: To purchase hair chemicals and hair rollers

loans.name: Damiana

texts.en:
Damiana A. is from the village of Calamagui. She is 49 years old, married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Damiana owns and operates a business venture providing manicure and pedicure services to local community members. Damiana has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2007, Damiana joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. Damiana is requesting a new loan of 27,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase materials needed to provide services. This loan will be her seventh from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Tusitukirewamu Nanziga Women's Group-Mpigi

texts.en: N. Winnie is a 40-year-old married woman with six children. Diligence is a virtue to her. In order to put food on her family’s table and manage the  costs of her children’s education, she has made painstaking efforts to oversee her fuel sales business at a local petrol station in Mpigi. Over the last 18 years she has built strength of character through integrity in her operations. Her customers have mostly been commercial motorcyclists. In a week, this happily married mother says she can make as much as 84,000 UGX. With this loan, she will buy more jerrycans of fuel for resale. Winnie belongs to Tusitukirewamu Group, Mpigi.

loans.use: To purchase more jerrycans of fuel for resale

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared G. is 26 years old and married to Jane Achieng. They have a baby who is only six months old. They live in Kakamega town.

Jared is in the business of making charcoal burners. He normally gets many orders from his clients as many people use these for cooking. He is based in the rural area where charcoal is affordable and many people prefer to buy the charcoal burners. He is applying for his second loan from KADET Ltd. after successfully completing the first one. His monthly income is KES 20000.

His hope is to one day be able to open a retail shop.

loans.use: To buy materials for molding charcoal burners

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 50 years old. Josephine is married and has five children. She is involved in hog-raising and farming. Based on her experience, farming has been very challenging. Among the challenges she faced are natural calamities. She says it helps to have more than one source of income. That's why she started raising hogs. Josephine works hard to augment her family's income.

Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizers and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and feeds

In 2010, Pehinia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and enable her to engage in business activities. loans.name: Dorotea

texts.en:
Dorotea P. is 38 years old, married, and lives in the province of Antique in the Philippines with her husband and five children. Dorotea is a pioneer member of her center and currently she is a center chief (leader). Being a leader, Dorotea has established good relationships with her group mates and in the center. She is also a good model, demonstrating a 100 per cent credit rating (basis of loans). To supply additional income for her family, Dorotea has opened a vegetable vending business in her neighborhood and at the market.
Dorotea has been enjoying spending the profits from her vegetable business. She has been able to sustain the needs of her five children and make small improvements to their lives. This has made Dorotea optimistic about working harder and aiming further in her business and family life, because she has her own business to support their financial needs and loans she can access to support her business. Therefore, Dorotea wants to take this opportunity to enlarge her business by requesting another loan of 33,000 PHP from Kiva lenders as additional business capital. She wants to buy a larger volume of stock for her business as well as attract more customers and secure the loyalty of her regular customers.
Dorotea's long-term goals are to have a successful vegetable sales business, fund college education for her siblings and support her family financially. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor. Dorotea’s aspiration to give her children a good life drives her commitment to her ventures.

loans.use: To buy a larger volume of vegetables to sell

She says part of her harvest is used for family consumption and the rest is sold in her community.

This is the second loan they have taken from FATEN. Hala and her husband were very good borrowers who repaid their first loan on time.
Hala’s husband appears in the picture here with their child as she is religious and doesn’t want her picture online.

texts.en:

The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. Norma wishes to have a successful business.

Norma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Nanesa is 40 years old and married to a businessman. She has five children, three of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children by paying their school fees.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew K. is 25 years old and from Misikhu area in Kakamega. He is single and has no dependants at the moment.
Andrew has been running a business rearing dairy cows for the past eight months. Most of his customers come to buy fresh milk from him but he also supplies milk to the shops around. He is applying for his first loan from Kiva partner, KADET, after being introduced to KADET by a friend who is already a client. Andrew intends to use his loan to buy another dairy cow to enable him to meet the demands of his customers who buy milk on daily basis for consumption. His hope and dream is to diversify into a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow to add to his stock

loans.name: Gulnora Mehmanova's Group

texts.en:
Gulnora M. is the leader of this group. She is 44 years old and a widow who has two daughters and three sons. All her children are students. In order to make money, Gulnora started to breed livestock 12 years ago. By reselling farm animals after fattening, she earns 3,500 KGS per month. With this loan, she wants to purchase livestock animals for breeding. In the future she wants to save money and open her own grocery store. Zarina B., 26, is the treasurer of the group. Six years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS, she started to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 11,700 KGS per month. She hopes to obtain a loan to purchase convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. Adam S., 58, is married. He has two sons and a daughter. His sons are working in Russia and his daughter is at school. Adam and his wife breed livestock to make money. With this loan, Adam wants to purchase more farm animals for breeding. In the future he plans to repair his house. Kudaiberdi A., 49, is married. He has a daughter and two sons. Kudaiberdi breeds livestock and his wife works in Russia. With this loan he wants to purchase two sheep for breeding. In the future he wants to build a new house.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff. arn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

texts.en:

She is applying for her first loan with KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is also a client here. She wants to buy ten sacks of Irish potatoes to add to her stock so as to be able to meet the demand of her clients.

Her hope and dream is to be the main supplier of Irish potatoes to the big hotels around.

loans.name: Mukhtar's Group

texts.en:
Mukhtar, 47, is a housewife who spends most of her time at home doing her household responsibilities. She lives an area of the city of Pakpattan named 16/SP with her husband, in a 3-room brick house and doesn’t have any children. Pakpattan is located in Pujnab and is famous for its sugar production. Her husband, M. H., has a business dealing in livestock. He buys animals from animal markets at cheap rates and raises them for resale. He started this business 15 years ago and he has become expert in it. His clientele base is butchers and he meets their orders and generates good profit. 

Mukhtar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan her husband will buy young animals and later sell them to his customers. She hopes that their family's living conditions will improve. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years she has proved herself a responsible client who never missed any meeting and paid installments on time.  

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Mukhta.

loans.use: To buy animals for animal-selling business

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a borrower from Hebron, married and a mother of 9 children, her husband is an employee of a very low salary, therefore Fatima wanted to help her husband and start a business to help covering household expenses, she started with the small amount of money she had and a loan from FATEN to buy sheep and raise it in the backyard of her house. 

After the forth loan from FATEN Fatima sensed the changes of family conditions to the better. Fatima came to FATEN and took a $2000 loan to purchase more sheep and increase the returns.

Fatima and her husband are receiving the loan in FATEN’s office in the picture above

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: The young woman in the photograph is Srey T., age 29, who lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang, which is the best territory for farming. Srey T. is a married woman. Srey T. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She and her husband are local farmers who have spent almost their whole life in the fields. They are able to plant crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. This rainy season, she doesn’t have funds yet to use on her farm. So, Srey T. is looking for a loan to buy fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
At the age of 55, Fely is already a widow, but continues to live and be productive for her six children: Alberto, 30, an electrician; Al Vinant, 24; Ruby Christine, 23; Al Jerald, 19; Al John, 17; and Maria, 14. Fely’s children describe her as a hardworking and tough mother. The thing that is always kept in her mind is that she will work as long as she can for herself and for her family.

Fely owns and operates an embroidery business. This became the main source of their income to use for their expenses and to buy things that they need. It continued to grow after Fely joined and got her first loan from Kiva field partner, Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI). Now she has asked for a loan for the improvement again of her business to have a better output. Specifically, the loan will be used to purchase raw materials needed for her embroidery business. She hopes soon to build a booth to sell her finished products. 

Fely is really hoping right now that her business will become stable for them to be able to live a sumptuous but simple life. Her long-term goals are for her last five children to complete college and to have stable jobs that will help her family move away from under the umbrella of poverty.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed for her embroidery business

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Pelba

texts.en:
Pelba T. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 57 years old, married and has four children. She is involved in farming and hog-raising. She plants and harvests rice crops. The pigs she raises are also sold to the market. Pelba is a hardworking mother. She wants the best for her family.

Pelba joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Pelba has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase feed and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and their house.

loans.use: To purchase feed and fertilizers

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn P. is from the village of Calamagui. She is 34 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,800 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jocelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza C. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Liloan, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband, Ericson C., works as a driver to earn his living. They have 2 children who are 4 and 10 years old. Liza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Liza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 7,000 PHP, thus raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan cycle, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for the business so that she can continue to save up for the future and support the needs of the family. Liza C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Daniel Junior Daniel

texts.pt:
Daniel Júnior Daniel C. nasceu na Província de Inhambane Sul de Moçambique, tem 27 anos de idade é solteiro e cem nenhum filho. Fez a 10ª classe não concluiu devido a falta de tempo, vive na casa dos tios e responsabiliza se pelos pais que vivem em Inhambane enviando lhes 500.00mt mensalmente.

Daniel sai de Inhambane para o Distrito de Namaacha com seu irmão, onde da continuidade dos seus estudos, teve que interromper quando arranja um emprego na saúde como Motorista. Devido ao horário de trabalho que tem feito em turnos não fixos, não foi possível continuar com seus estudos. É funcionário permanente ha 5 anos auferindo 3.100.00mt que aplica nas despesas da casa e da sua obra.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas que são clientes desta instituição. Este é seu segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (telhas, barrotes pregos e outros) para cobertura da sua casa. O anterior empréstimo de 7.000.00mt foi também para compra de material de construção.

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para adquirir mobiliário da sua casa.
texts.en:
Daniel was born in the Inhambane Province, South Mozambique. He is 27 years old, single and has no children. He completed 10th grade but didn't finish school due to lack of time. He lives in his aunt and uncle's home and takes care of his parents who live in Inhambane by sending them 500 meticais every month. 

Daniel left Inhambane to the Namaacha District with his brother. He continued his studies there but had to stop when he got a job as a driver with the Health Department. Due to his working different shifts he could not finish school. He has been a permanent employee for 5 years making 3,100 meticais which he spends with household expenses and his construction. 

He has never had loans with other banks. He came to know Hluvuku through colleagues who are clients of the institution. This is his second loan with Hluvuku and first with Kiva, in the amount of 10,000 meticais. He plans to use it to purchase construction materials (tiles, beams, nails and others) for roofing. The previous loan was for 7,000 meticais and was also used to buy construction materials. 

He is confident he will pay ahead of schedule and request another loan to furnish his home.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (tiles, beams, nails and others)

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M., 32, has been operating a grocery store in Nyalenda estate in Kisumu City for the past 11 years. She sells cereals, fruit, and vegetables, earning a profit of 27,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). She is married to Daniel Nyangau who is a police officer. They have two children aged nine and two-and-a-half.

She has been with KADET Ltd and she is applying for a fourth loan of 50,000 KES, which she intends to use to purchase more stock of cereals, (three sacks of maize, two sacks of beans, one sack of rice, and one sack of green grams) and add more fruits of vegetables. With the anticipated profit she plans to pay school fees for her children.

In the future she desires to expand her business, get a good stall in the town centre, and open a wholesale shop. She wishes to send  her children to good schools.

loans.use: purchasing cereals, fruits, & vegetables

loans.name: Cheryl Marie

texts.en: Cheryl Marie V. is a single woman who lives in Brgy. Caceres, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a small eatery. Cheryl Marie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Cheryl Marie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 29,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 6000 PHP, thus raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th cycle loan, she is again borrowing 29,500 PHP which she intends to use as additional capital for her small eatery so that she can continue to save up for the future, especially that of her children. Cheryl Marie V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty K.  is currently in the business of selling fish, groundnuts (peanuts), beans, and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts and beans to sell.  Betty is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a builder. She has 2 children and only 1 child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: buying bags of groundnut and beans to resell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is 50 years old and a member of Tumaini Rongai under Faulu Kenya.  She rents out houses and she runs the business with four employees.  She has been engaged in this business for ten years.  She hopes to construct more rental houses in the future.  For this reason, she has requested 30,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES). In five years, she hopes to build apartments for renting.

loans.use: To construct rental houses

loans.name: Corsine

texts.en: Corsine F. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Poblacion, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fish vending and pig fattening businesses. Her husband, Carlito F. Sr., age 31, works as a fisherman to earn his living. They have three children who are 5 to 10 years old. This picture was taken after the center meeting because her fish business was already sold out early in the morning. Corsine joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Corsine has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000; thus, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her fish vending business. She will continue to save up for the future and meet the daily needs of her family. Corsine F. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Meshack

texts.en: Meshack is 24 years old and a hardworking man.  He runs a retail shop for a living.  Apart from that, he distributes bread.  His business is located in a very busy location and most of his customers are people from his community.  He has been in business for four years, and he has managed to employ two people.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to keep business records.  He has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy cooking fat, sugar, soap and flour.  He hopes to own a mini-supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To buy cooking fat, sugar, soap and flour

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen lives in small city in Pakistan called Pakpattan. It is located in Punjab and is known for its sugar production. Perveen lives with her family in a two-room brick house. She has given birth to two daughters, 12-year-old Shaista and 8-year-old Sania, who are attending school in 5th and 2nd class respectively. 

Perveen is an active lady, operating a milk business from home and also selling shawls (a cloth worn over the shoulders and upper body) in her area to earn extra income for her family. Her husband, M. A., has a small piece of land and grows wheat on it. After cultivating the wheat, he sells it to different wheat sellers and earns good profit on it. He has been in this business for the past eight years. 

Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy seeds, fertilizer, etc., for growing wheat and getting the maximum output from his land. Perveen is confident that her husband will get good production from his land using the loan money. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. She has proved herself as a responsible client, paying her installments on time and never missing any meetings. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for growing wheat

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou R. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Tan-awan, Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: fish vending and pig fattening. Her husband, Misael R., who is 37 years old, works as a driver to earn his living.  They have three children who are 6 to 14 years old. Marilou joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marilou has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase more fish to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future and for her family. Marilou R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  Photo was taken at the center because her business was sold out early in the morning. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Loice

texts.en: Loice B. is currently in the business of selling fish and chickens at Dar es salam market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish to sell. Loice is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

loans.use: To stock more fish to sell.

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mrs. Uk S. is a 42-year-old married woman and local farmer who has been living in province of Kompong Chhnang. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. Her children, who are all teenagers, study at public school. Mrs. Uk S. has raised a lot of piglets and she had hoped to sell them to buyers three or four months after she began raising them. Unfortunately, the pigs are not big enough, due to the lack of food. To help solve this problem, Mrs. Uk S. would like to request a loan from Kiva to buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs. Mrs. Uk S. was not available at the time of the photo, so her husband is shown instead.

loans.use: To buy many sacks of pig feed to fatten her pigs.

loans.name: Mose

texts.en: Mose is 23 years old and single. He has been running a retail shop for three years. His business is located in the urban area. He has seen his business grow since he joined Faulu Kenya. He was formerly working as a van driver. He says that he is an aggressive businessman and he hopes that one day, he will own a wholesale shop. With the loan of 40, 000 KES, he will buy sugar, flour and cooking fat.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour and cooking fat.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 52 years old. Rebecca is married and has 6 school-aged children. She is involved in farming. She has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than a few years now. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale. Rebecca hopes to have a stable income to sustain her children's education.

Rebecca joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and feeds.

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en: Zipporah is 30 years old, married and blessed with a three-year-old child. She joined unity Power group in Faulu Kenya as a business-lady who runs a grocery. Though her business is located in a very competitive environment, she still has a number of reliable customers. Her husband, who is employed, also supports her financially. She has requested for 40, 000 Kes to buy grains. She hopes to enlarge her business and become a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy grains.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en: Sharon is a member of Kiserian Victory group in Faulu Kenya.  She runs a cafeteria to earn a living.  It has been two years since she started the business and she has managed to employ three people.  She says that she has become more focused in her business since she joined Faulu Kenya. She sees herself owning a big hotel in five years.  She has requested 40, 000 Kes to buy utensils.

loans.use: To buy utensils

loans.name: Maria Rona

texts.en: Maria Rona A. is a 42 year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: Ready-To-Wear clothing sales and an Avon dealer business. She lives in Sitio Sangay, Barangay Purisima, Manapla, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1994 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Ready-To-Wear clothing and Avon dealer businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000. Maria Rona is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more stock for her Ready-To-Wear clothing business. This will be her 24th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Maria Rona aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of Ready-To-Wear clothing to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios C. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 52 years old, married and has 4 children. Her eldest child is 26 years old and the youngest is 12. She is a hog grower and a farmer. She earns through planting and harvesting rice and also from selling the pigs she grows. She hopes for her ventures to improve and give her family a better income. Remedios works hard to improve the living conditions of her family.

Remedios joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Remedios is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: Estrella G. is from the village of Barangay Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 56 years old, married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business buying and selling fruit in the local community. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sejerina

texts.en: Sejerina S. is currently in the business of selling sugar, rice and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar to sell. She is 39 years old and married to a policeman. She has five children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a business selling clothes.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar to sell

loans.name: Benard

texts.en: Benard is 31 years old and single. For a living, he sells stationary and has employed one person. Besides that, he runs a retail shop for extra income (the photo was taken in his retail shop). He was previously employed as a computer specialist before he started his business. He says that he is doing well in his business which is just one year old. He hopes to expand the business and own a big bookshop in the future. He has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy stationary.

loans.use: To buy stationary

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en: Luzminda D. is a 59-year-old married woman who supports her family by farming and fishing. She lives in Purok Sampaguita, Brgy. Talacagay, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. Luzminda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming and fishing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Luzminda is now borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her farmland. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey towards economic freedom. Luzminda aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Naheed's Group

texts.en:
Naheed lives in a small city in Pakistan called Pakpattan It is located in Punjab and known for its sugar production. She lives in the small area named 16SP. She is 38 years old and settled here in a three-room brick house four years ago. She is married to M. S. and has no children. Her husband has a business of livestock. He has been doing this business for the last 15 years. He buys young animals from animal markets at cheap rates, raises them and resells them at a good profit. 

Naheed has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy young animals (goats & cows) and grow his business. She is hopeful that by using his 15 years of experience, her husband will be able to get positive results from his business. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client who has paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy animals for animal selling business

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro B. is from the village of Bungad. He is 46 years old. Pedro is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Pedro owns & operates a business catching and selling fresh-water fish at the market. Pedro has been engaged in his business for over 36 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pedro joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Pedro is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Pedro from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 32-year-old married lady. She makes and sells curios and woven baskets to earn a living. She also gets financial support from her husband who is employed. She has been in her business for four years. She is thankful to Faulu Kenya for supporting her financially – this has led to growth in her business. So far, she has managed to employ three people. She hopes to expand her business to other towns in the future. She has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy raw materials such as bamboo and metal for making her products.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as bamboo and metals

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man with two children, ages 2 and 5. He has been selling clothes for 3 years. He was previously employed before he went into this business. He hopes to expand his business in the future. 

Joseph has been a registered member of Faulu Kenya with the Green Tree Group. Through the group, he had previously received a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). He has requested another loan of 80,000 KES to buy clothes for resale. Joseph sees himself opening more outlets for his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Jane Jepkemoi

texts.en:
Jane Jepkemoi T. is 37 years old and married to Christopher Kipsat Chemweno, who is a businessman. Her business is a source of additional income for the family. They have one school-going child, age 15. They live in Iten - Eldoret, Kenya. Jane sells leather, clothing and shoes and has been in business for 10 years. She earns a monthly profit of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

Jane learned about KADET through a credit officer. She is applying for her fourth loan of 75,000 KES from KADET, which she intends to use to buy more shoes of all sizes. With the anticipated profit, she plans to expand her business more and more. In the future, Jane wishes to open a supermarket in Iten - Eldoret town and to live a more comfortable life with her family.

loans.use: To buy more shoes of all sizes

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas C. is a hardworking lady of 27 years who is married to Naftali Terer. Together they have one child aged four years. They live in Kipkaren estate in Eldoret, Kenya. She has been operating a hotel for the past three years and earns a monthly income of 10,000 KES.

When Dorcas learned about KADET and having no history with any other MFI, she applied for her first loan of 20,000 KES from them. Dorcas intends to purchase plastic chairs for the hotel. She plans to use the profits from upgrading her hotel to expand her business.

Dorcas hopes to grow her business and to see her children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To purchase plastic chairs

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina E. is a widow who lives in Sitio Sangay within Barangay Purisima, Manapla municipality, Negros Occidental province in the western Visayas islands. She has two businesses: pig fattening and food vending.

Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 21 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, thus lifting the family's standard of living.

This time for her 22nd loan cycle, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP which she intends to use to purchase feed for her piggery so that she can continue to save up for future household consumption and savings. Gina E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her piggery

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia J. is a 63-year old married woman who supports her family by running a general store and food vending business. She lives in Lower Calasa within Caradio-an, a barangay of Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental province in the western Visayas islands. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and at her food vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 6,000 PHP.

Lilia is now borrowing 14,000 PHP so that she can purchase more inventory to sell. This will be her fifteenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lilia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.
