loans.use: To purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Marineth

texts.en:
Marineth J., age 42, runs a general store, where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Marineth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Marineth lives with her husband and seven school-aged children in the village of Palutan.

In 2009, Marineth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Marineth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marineth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marineth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz, age 26, sews clothing to earn additional income to help her husband support the family. She gets a good number of orders every month due to the quality of the apparel she makes. Her husband, M. A., age 30, raises and sells animals for a living.  

Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to apply toward her husband’s business. With the loan, M. will buy young goats to raise and offer for sale. Shahnaz knows that her husband will make positive use of the loan money. He makes a good amount of money each time he sells an animal, allowing him to improve the living standard of his family.  

This is Shahnaz's second loan application through Asasah. In the previous loan year, she has proved herself a responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings. 

Shahnaz lives with her family in a two-room brick house in a small area known as 16SP in the city of Pakpattan, an area in Pakistan known for its sugar production. They settled in the region six years ago. They have two daughters, both illiterate due to the poor financial condition of the family.

loans.use: To buy animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng S. is a 30-year-old woman who is a garment worker in Kompong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Heng S. has been working since 2009 and has a formal salary. She has a life partner in her husband (pictured) who works in the farm field. The couple helps each other to earn money to feed their two kids. Both of the kids are attending school. Mrs. Heng S. is concerned that she has another farm, but she is not planting crops on it. She hopes to use her Kiva loan to purchase seed and fertilizer for growing. She proposes to use the remainder of loan to buy equipment for repairing her old car.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for growing.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena C. is from the village of Palutan, San Mariano, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Elena is widowed and has six adult children. To make a living, Elena owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Elena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2007, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Elena is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Elena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna A. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Maningcao, Sibulan, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  Fruits & Vegetables Vending and Selling Standing Crops. Her husband, Modesto A., who is 49 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  They have three children who are 17 to 27 years old.  Lorna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lorna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business assets. Lorna A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

 About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Gulshada

texts.en:
Gulshada C., age 43, sells clothes at market. After graduating from technical university, she got married and became the mother of four children. Her family started to engage in field crop cultivation, but this was not a very profitable activity and it did not cover the expenses of the large family. Gulshada and her family decided to move to the town of Tokmok, to her sister’s house. There, in order to find means of subsistence, Gulshada started to sell clothes at the local market. Using her initial capital of 5,000 KGS, she worked hard and managed to raise her floating capital. 

At the beginning of 2010, in order to grow her business, Gulshada applied to Bai-Tushum and Partners for her first loan, which was used to purchase a small shop. The loan amount was applied as intended and repaid without any delays. 

Now Gulshada wants to take out a loan of 80,000 KGS to expand her range of products for the winter season in her shop. With the revenues, Gulshada plans to pay for the education of her children. She strives ever forward and dreams that her children will become progressive people. In the future, Gulshada plans to buy a house for her family.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase a greater assortment of clothing to sell at market

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda Cañete earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a chainsaw rental service, and a farming business. Her husband, Sonny Cañete, age 49, works as a chainsaw operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 12 children who are between the ages of 8 and 30. The family lives in Gilside, Brgy. Nabulao, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. 

Florenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired toward something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florenda has been working hard and incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, which helped to improve the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to purchase an expanded inventory for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Florenda Cañete is truly a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Aires

texts.en: Aires P. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Liloan, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living running a general store and food vending business. Her husband, Rolden P., age 34, works as a driver. They have two children who are 6 and 10 years old. Aires joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Aires has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 13,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future to send her children to school. Aires P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. loans.name: Kafa

texts.en:
Kafa is a married woman from Jenin city in Northern Palestine; her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a salary which barely covers household expenses.
Kafa’s husband want to improve their life, therefore he will start a small business with friends and start selling cars. Kafa’s husband saved a good amount of money and needs $2000 to start; therefore she came to FATEN and received the needed amount.
Kafa’s husband appears in the picture here in FATEN’s office when receiving the loan as Kafa is a religious woman and doesn’t want her picture published

loans.use: Start cars business

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia C. is a 45-year old married woman who supports her family by running a vegetable plantation. She lives in Lower Ilian within Barangay Dumarao, a part of Roxas municipality, Palawan province on the island region of MIMAROPA. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard on her vegetable plantation, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 PHP.

Julia is now borrowing 12,500 PHP so that she can use it as additional working capital. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Julia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: For additional working capital for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old single woman living with her parents and one sister. She is from Lebanon. She has been working as a tailor since 1995. She also sells lingerie from her shop. She cooperates with her sister to support their father with the family expenses. She is well known by the the members of her town, and she has a good business reputation.

Today, she is requesting $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to invest in purchasing new lingerie collections in addition to tailoring tools to increase her sales and so her income.

loans.use: To purchase new lingerie collections in addition to more tailoring tools

loans.name: Dam

texts.en:
Dam T., age 50, is married to Sokum, age 43. She has five children, two of whom are employed. One is a construction worker and the other, a garment worker; the other three are attending school. Her husband has been earning a living for many years by playing music for people who want him to play for their ceremonies, while Dam T. has a plot of land for farming.

Dam T. and her husband have earned a better income since her first two children grew up. Sokum has a motorbike, but he wants to put it to use to earn extra income, and it is a good time for that. Because of that, Dam T. has decided to seek a loan of $400 from Kiva, which she will use for her husband to buy a cart to connect to his motorbike to run a transport business.

loans.use: To buy a cart to connect to her husband's motorbike

loans.name: Joseph  Maara

texts.en:
Joseph is a tomato vendor. He has operated his business for five years and earns a good income. He was introduced to KADET Ltd by an existing member of the group and is now applying for his third loan in the amount of Kshs. 34,000 after paying his previous loans in a timely manner. With this loan, he intends to add a larger stock of tomatoes to offer for wholesale distribution.

Joseph is married and has grown-up children. With the profits from his improved business, he plans to renovate his rental houses so as to get maximum profits. Joseph intends eventually to make his living as a landlord and be able to provide for his family's basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase a larger stock of tomatoes to offer for wholesale distribution

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz A. earns her living by operating two business ventures: buying and selling vegetables and spices, and a vegetable farming businesses. Her husband, Romeo A., age 45, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have one child, age 11. The family in  lives in Upper Ilian, Brgy. Dumarao, Roxas, Palawan.

Luz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired toward something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luz has been working hard and incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, which helped to improve the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her eighth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for the future education of their child. Luz A. is truly a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Erdenebayar

texts.en: Mr.Erdenebayar is 23 years old and lives with his wife and son, who attends a local kindergarten. Erdenebayar’s wife is a kitchen assistant at Baylag Dinery. They don’t have their own place to live at the moment. They are living in his wife’s aunt’s place in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Mr.Erdenebayar runs an on-call computer repair service, 1 hour photo service and printing service. He started this business with two of his friends, 2 years ago. He has gained a lot of experience since then. He is a very energetic, inventive person. He started this business with two printers, two digital cameras and two computers. He is planning to purchase a ger for his family. This is his second loan from this MFI and he has a good repayment history. He is requesting a loan of 500,000 tugriks to extend his business by setting up a new stall for selling different computer hardware and gadgets.

loans.use: To set up a new stall for selling different computer hardware and gadgets

loans.name: Nkuyata Ole

texts.en:
Nkuyata Ole N., age 48, is a wheat farmer. He supports seven people in his family. He and his wife, Simalo N., have five children between the ages of six and 18. Simalo is a housewife and also helps Nkuyata in his farming activity.

Nkuyata has farmed wheat for 12 years. This will be his second loan and he is planning to spend ksh 50,000 to buy chemicals and fertilizer, and ksh 30,000 to spray his wheat farm.

He is planning to use the anticipated profits from his farm to expand his farming activity by leasing a bigger piece of land in order to increase his wheat production. His dream is to become a large-scale farmer, owning a bigger piece of land, and becoming more financially stable to better support his family.

loans.use: To buy pestcides and fertilizer and to spray the wheat farm

loans.name: Julius Gunza

texts.en:
Julius Gunza K. has been a carpenter for 10 years in Soy Eldoret, Kenya. He is 47 years old, married to Damary Gunza and they have four children aged 35, 32, 30 and 26. Julius' wife is a teacher and she provides an added income for the family. Julius earns a profit of KES 20,000 per month from his carpentry business.

Julius is applying to KADET LTD for his first loan of KES 25,000, which he is planning to use to buy lockers and velvet material for sofa sets. He wants to use the anticipated profits from the expanded business to educate his children and support his family. Julius hopes and dreams of owning a bigger carpentry business.

loans.use: to buy lockers and velvet material for making sofa sets

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita S. is a 60-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a pig fattening business. She lives in Purok 5, Daan Lungsod, Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her pig fattening business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,500. Nenita is now borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can purchase additional pigs and feed. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Nenita hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs and feed

loans.name: Taikoh Ole

texts.en:
Taikoh is married and has three children whom he supports. Taikoh was introduced to KADET through a credit officer; he is serving his first loan and has not joined any other MFI. 

Taikoh has been in the butchery business for six years. His business is located in a busy open air market. As the region's population is large, the business attracts many customers. With this loan, Taikoh will enlarge his butchery, by buying an oven to prepare roast meat and tables and seats for customers to use as they eat. With the extra profits, Taikoh will purchase land. He hopes to stop paying rent and own land where he will build his home and his business premises. Taikoh believes he is hardworking.

loans.use: to enlarge his butchery, by buying an oven, tables and seats

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma G., a married woman who lives in Purok 6, Daan Lungsod, Toledo City, Cebu, earns her living by operating three enterprises: a general store, a frozen products retail operation, and an electronic reloading business. Her husband, Jose G., 60, works as a Winsman Operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have eight children ranging in age from 22 to 37 years old.

Thelma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Thelma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 to purchase more stocks to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Thelma G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Naatasim Ole

texts.en:
Naatasim Ole S., age 37, is a farmer. He owns his own piece of land and has been forming it for the past 12 years. He and his wife, Noolamala S., have five school-going children. 

Naatasim learned about KADET through a friend who is already a client in the organization. This will be his second loan. He plans to spend ksh 30,000 on buying fertilizer and chemicals for his ten-acre wheat farm, and the remaining ksh 20,000 on spraying the wheat.

He is planning to buy some farm equipment with the anticipated profit from his expanded farming activity.

Naatasim is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chemicals and to pay for spraying the wheat crop

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina T. earns her living by operating a networking business. Her husband, Rolando T., age 57, works as an electrician to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children between the ages of 7 and 24. Two of her children are already working while the other four attend school. The family lives in Prk. Caticong, Brgy. Cabadiangan, Compostela, Cebu City. 

Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired toward something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina  has been working hard and incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, which has helped raise the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her networking business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Gina T. is truly a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Ezekiel Lesinko

texts.en:
Ezekiel Lesinko K. is 33 years old and married to Ether K.. He supports six people in his family. Ezekiel has been farming for the last six years. His farm is in a productive area which has proved to be good for wheat farming.

Ezekiel learned about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to use to buy pesticides to spray on the growing wheat to prevent it from being invaded by pests. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for wheat. His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and have his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his growing wheat

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana D. is a 54-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 3 business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, pig fattening and a machine shop. She lives in Brgy. Pandan, Bogo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her three businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. Ana is now borrowing PHP 14,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Ana hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a mother of four daughters and three sons, her husband Samer owns a grocery store in Tulkarem, Amal and her husband run the store which helps them cover household expenses and children school expenses.

Amal and her husband came to FATEN as they needed to increase the returns from the store. Amal came to FATEN for a loan to increase their stock and have more goods exhibited in their store.

Amal’s husband Samer appears in the picture here as the family is very conservative and Amal doesn’t want to appear in the picture

loans.use: Improve the store

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina P. is a married woman who lives in Bliss, Brgy. La Paz, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a general store and curtain sales. Her husband, Gaspar Jupiter P., 44 years old, works overseas to earn his living. They have 1 child who is 16 years old. Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 which she intends to use as additional working capital for her general store and curtain sales business so that she can continue to save up for her daughter's future education. Gina P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida N. lives in the Kamwokya Kifumbira neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has six children, five of whom are in school.  Hamida has a retail business selling cooked food.  She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days a week.  Hamida sells her food products in a shop.  She has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more foodstuffs, including bananas, sweet potatoes, cassava, rice, and beef.

The main business challenges for Hamida include the rainy season and transportation of foodstuffs from the market to her place of work.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked hotel and to start doing outside catering.  Hamida lives in a home that she rents; she does not have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and medication.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs, including bananas, sweet potatoes, cassava, rice, and beef

loans.name: Koitalel Ole

texts.en:
Koitalel is married and has three children whom he and his wife support.  Koitalel was introduced to KADET through a credit officer; he is requesting his first loan from KADET, and he is also a client of K-REP, another microfinance institution in Kenya.  Koitalel has been a livestock trader for five years.  He will use the KADET loan to buy livestock for his business and to meet basic family needs, for example, school fees for his children.

Koitalel's business is located in a busy open-air market; the population is large, so there are many customers.  He will use the extra profits he makes to open a butcher shop in the market.

Koitalel hopes to become a big trader; he describes himself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for his business and to meet basic family needs

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is a young woman from Jenin who is married and has no children. Salma’s husband works in the across the border (in Israel) and also owns a small grocery store. he wants to have a decent job and more returns out of the store, therefore his wife Salma came to FATEN ask for this help purchasing goods and basic items to sell in the store.

Salma will be running the store till it prospers and her husband would be able to quit his job across the border (in Israel).

The store is located in a rural area where they have more chances to attract a good number of clients.
Salma appears in the picture above in FATEN’s office.

loans.use: Purchase grocery store goods
